Award.AwardTitle: A Dual Isotope Conundrum: Unraveling a Cryptic Subsurface N Cycle
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nitrogen is an essential macronutrient that largely regulates primary productivity across a host of global ecosystems. Through human activities, global turnover of N has more than doubled, resulting in massive and widespread alteration of fundamental ecosystem dynamics leading to pronounced impacts on both human and ecological health. An accurate understanding of the (bio)geochemical cycling of N is, therefore, of central importance to enabling the prediction of its fate in the environment. This project aims to quantify linkages between the N and Fe cycles in the subsurface terrestrial biosphere, through a comprehensive examination of the biotic and abiotic interactions between NO3- (and NO2-) and Fe and their influence on the dual isotopic composition (e.g., delta 15N and delta 18O) of NO3- in the environment. Specifically, there exists a fundamental discrepancy of coupled N and O isotope effects between microbial culture-based isotopic studies of denitrification and field-based isotopic measurements of groundwater NO3- loss under anaerobic conditions (in which denitrification is widely implicated). We suggest that this discrepancy is the result of a ubiquitous, yet largely unrecognized, coupling of abiotic and/or biotic Fe cycling with both reductive and anaerobic oxidative N cycling pathways and have preliminary data supporting this hypothesis. Testing of this hypothesis will help reveal the underlying causes of this apparent isotope conundrum and will have important implications for improving our understanding of the coupling of subsurface N, C and Fe cycling in the terrestrial subsurface.

This project will also support the development of an annual 2-day teacher-training workshop in support of Science, Technology, Engineering and Math education in Massachusetts. We will partner with the Waquoit Bay National Estuarine Research Reserve (WBNERR) to conduct a workshop (about 15 high school teachers) focused on wastewater issues in watersheds and nitrogen cycling in coastal ecosystems. The workshop will provide participants with an understanding of the natural nitrogen cycle, human impacts and environmental effects and approaches for minimizing the impact of anthropogenic N loading in local watersheds and fragile coastal ecosystems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this project was improve our understanding of how natural cycles of nitrogen and iron interact in the environment – specifically under anoxic or reducing conditions – and to better understand how these interactions might be recorded in the naturally occurring stable isotopes of the nitrogen cycle. Under reducing redox conditions, either through the activity of iron-reducing bacteria or even indirectly by certain chemical species (e.g., sulfide), common iron oxide minerals can be reductively dissolved and release soluble Fe(II). Under the same type of conditions, nitrate (NO3-), a widespread form of inorganic nitrogen commonly encountered in high levels as an anthropogenically-derived contaminant, can also be respired by bacteria via denitrification. During this process, nitrite (NO2-) is formed as a transient intermediate before being further reduced, ultimately to a gaseous form of nitrogen and released to the atmosphere. Denitrification is one of the major pathways by which excess reactive nitrogen is removed from the biosphere and returned to the atmosphere – primarily as inert N2 gas – but also to some degree as a powerful climatically active trace gas – nitrous oxide (N2O).

Where redox conditions and hence these redox reactions (e.g., iron reduction and denitrification) may fluctuate over time or space – such as in soils, groundwaters, tidal or freshwater marshes or lake sediments – it is easy to imagine that these two common and highly reactive chemical species Fe(II) and NO2- may interact. Indeed previous studies have shown that these two species react rapidly with one another under a variety of conditions – a process known as ‘chemodenitrification’ – and that this process has the potential to produce very high amounts of N2O. Nevertheless, evaluating whether this processes plays an important role in the environmental cycling of iron and nitrogen remains challenging.

To this end – we focused on developing and calibrating stable isotopic tools for improving the possibility of recognizing and quantifying the occurrence of this process and its contribution to N2O production. We conducted a series of studies designed to quantitatively characterize the stable nitrogen and oxygen isotope effects when NO2- is chemically reduced by Fe(II) – laying important groundwater for evaluating whether the dual isotopic dynamics of chemodenitrification might enable quantification of this process under natural conditions in future studies.

Experiments evaluated the N and O isotope effects of nitrite consumption by chemodenitrification across a variety of reaction conditions including pH, reactant concentrations and the binding environment of the Fe(II) – whether freely aqueous, bound in mineral structures or bound onto mineral surfaces (Buchwald et al., 2016; Grabb et al., in review). In two related studies, we found that factors leading to faster reaction rates between Fe(II) and nitrite – such as high Fe(II) concentrations, higher pH and surface coordination of Fe(II) (e.g., Fe(II) sorbed onto and within mineral surfaces) – played a central role in how the nitrogen and oxygen isotopes of the NO2- pool evolved. These factors also played a key role in determining the relative amount of N2O produced by these reactions as well as its unique intramolecular isotopic signature (15N ‘site preference’). By establishing well-defined relationships between reaction rates and the isotopic signatures of the reaction – these studies help to increase the utility of stable isotopes of both NO2- and N2O by better understanding the nature of isotopic fractionation by chemodenitrification.

Finally – in the context of this study we also developed a dual isotope numerical model that simulated evolving pools of NO3- and NO2- under a variety of cycling scenarios, with the goal of evaluating underlying cycling mechanisms that might explain the apparent decades-long discrepancy between the behavior of dual NO3- isotopes in groundwater- and marine-hosted denitrifying systems (Granger and Wankel, 2016). Our results suggest that denitrification must operate in close connection with other pervasive yet cryptic re-oxidation mechanisms – some of which may even prove to be novel. Our findings specifically highlight the apparent importance of bacterial NO2- oxidation in marine denitrifying systems, yet in contrast, reveals an evident importance for anammox in groundwater aquifers. Future work should aim to target differentiating the distribution of these pathways – with our model architecture providing a useful framework for testing these hypotheses.
